structure.text: The Laboratory (full official name is Microwave Spectroscopy Department) was organized in 1977, with the establishment of IAP RAS. The Laboratory was formed on the base of works of the group by A.F. Krupnov in NIRFI, which led to developments of submillimeter wave spectrometer with Backward Wave Oscillators (BWOs) and acoustic detection (RAD) and the phase lock-in system of submillimeter BWOs (both in 1970). Both those developments proved to be very successful and gave good perspective for many further developments of submillimeter wave spectroscopic technique and investigations of molecular spectra (see Instruments and List of publications). The department of microwave spectroscopy was the first in the new Institute to recieve the USSR State Prize in Science (1980, “For Development of Submillimeter Wave Spectroscopy with Backward Wave Oscillators”). Current activity of the Laboratory is presented on the site. A.F. Krupnov headed the Laboratory from 1977 to 2005; at the present M.Yu. Tretyakov is the Head of the Laboratory.

about_press.title: Press about water on the Sun

structure.text:
...Oleg Polyansky and Jonathan Tennyson of University College London and their colleagues say in last week's Science (V. 277, P. 346) that they have used computers to work out what the infrared spectrum of a watery sunspot at 3000 °C should look like. Comparing it with the real thing, they found an almost perfect match... (issue 2092 of New Scientist magazine, July 26, 1997, page 25)

...The team was led by Oleg Polyansky, a theoretician from Russia's Institute of Applied Physics; Nizhny Novgorod, who works with co-researcher Jonathan Tennyson, a physicist at University College, London; and UW chemistry Prof. Peter Bernath, an expert in molecular astronomy. Other team members included Serena Viti, Nikolay Zobov, Lloyd Wallace. In their 1995 study, the team recorded evidence of water — not in liquid form because the Sun is too hot, but as vapor or steam — in dark sunspots... (University of Waterloo Press Release No. 115 — July 17, 1997)

...Dr. Oleg Polyansky and colleagues at University College London and Russian Academy of Sciences report today in the journal Science that water does indeed exist on the Sun... (The Daily Telegraph, July 18, 1997)

...scientists have spotted the equivalent of the snowflake in hell. They have confirmed the presence of water on the Sun... (The Guardian, July 18, 1997)

...Spectrometers pointed at the Sun — which monitor the electromagnetic radiation given off by atomic bonds as they vibrate — give results identical to those predicted by the computer models, showing that water molecules are present in sunspot areas... (The Independent, July 18, 1997)

about_Williams.title: Methods of Experimental Physics. Volume 13. Part B. Spectroscopy. Ed. D. Williams. Acad. Press. 1976

structure.text:
4.   Molecular Spectroscopy
4.3 Microwave Region (by D. Johnson & R. Pearson)
…An entirely different approach to submm spectroscopy has been developed by Krupnov and co-workers. …BWO's have already been successfully employed by Krupnov <…> in broad band spectroscopic experiments… [they] are presently using condenser microphones as microwave detectors…

(Pp. 108, 114, 128–131)

RAS.title: Annual Report of Presidium of Russian Academy of Sciences

structure.text:
“In the field of Physical Sciences (direction “Contemporary problems of radiophysics”) in the year of 2012 the most interesting was the registration of resolved rotational spectrum of water dimer (H2O)2 in water vapor at room temperature in the millimeter wave range.” (P. 29)

Full report text in Russian

…NEW DIRECTIONS
After this brief review of the early history of microwave spectroscopy, which some of you never knew and others of you have forgotten, I wish to mention some of the results which the leaders of the second generation of microwave spectroscopists are getting and to indicate the directions in which they appear to be leading. Further extension of coherent submillimeter wave spectroscopy:

A second-generation microwave spectroscopist, A.F. Krupnov, has had notable success in extending coherent-sweep submillimeter wave spectroscopy beyond the frequency of 813 GHz, which we at Duke reached in 1970. With a strong primary source, a new BWO tube, and an acoustic detector, he has constructed a sweep spectrometer that operates with high sensitivity to frequencies slightly above 1000 GHz…

(Pp. 22–23)
(Applied Optics, V. 14, No. 1, January 1975, P. 8)

…An example of the second type of millimeter and submillimeter wave spectrometer of great potential is the instrument developed by Krupnov and co-workers (refs. 14, 15) who employ backward wave oscillators as radiation sources without frequency multiplication, and acoustical detection of the absorption signal… This type of spectrometer is a) a very wide band instrument (200 GHz to 1.3 THz), b) Doppler limited in resolution and c) with outstanding sensitivity…

(Pp. 510–511)

I should try to point to particular landmarks in the development of the field which originated in Europe. It must be admitted that many of the most basic advances belong of necessity to the early American-dominated period. European landmarks to which I can point certainly include the first use of microwave-microwave double resonance spectroscopy by Professor Gozzini and his colleagues at the University of Pisa in 1959 (ref. 10), and the striking studies at short wavelengths with acoustic detectors made by Dr. Krupnov and his group in the U.S.S.R. from about 1970.

…Microwave Spectroscopy
Perhaps the most important development in the Spectroscopy of the microwave region in this decade has been the discovery of microwave signals from molecules in interstellar dust clouds. <…> Another technical development is the introduction of acoustic detection, especially in the millimeter region. Krupnov has reported very successful results with this means of detection, which also appears promising for low resolution Spectroscopy where higher pressure samples can then be advantageously used (with consequent increase in band intensity) without the limitation set by arcing in Stark detection…

(P. 17)
Study of microwave and submillimeter-wave spectra of the mixed deuterated-protonated water-dimer isotopomers produced in pulse-nozzle molecular beam (JMS, 181, 229–245 (1997)).

Development of modern broadband millimeter-wave resonator spectroscopy on the base of fast sweeping frequency synthesizer. Measurements of dielectrical properties of solid, liquid and gaseous samples in particular studies of atmospheric molecular lines. The spectrometer has essential advantages among all other known analogs (JMS, 202, 107–115 (2000)).

Spectrum of water molecule recorded with high sensitivity by use of cavity-rind-down spectrometer in the range 555–604 nm was analyzed on the basis of first principles variational calculations (JMS, 205, 117–121 (2001)).

Precision measurement of shifting and broadening parameters of the 183 GHz water line by pressure of various atmospheric gases using our spectrometer with Radio Acoustic Detection (JMS, 230, 196–198 (2005)).
Study of submillimeter-wave spectrum of H2O–HF dimer in equilibrium gas phase with continuous frequency scanning microwave spectrometer RAD-3 (JMS, 241, 124–135 (2007)).
Spectroscopy underlying microwave remote sensing of atmospheric water vapor (JMS, 328, 7–26 (2016)).
R. Saykally, “Simplest Water Cluster Leaves Behind its Spectral Fingerprint”
